title: Why was the Eastern Front so bloody? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Eastern Front was so bloody due to the factors and elements of distance, time, ideology, dictatorial tactics, surprise, population, technology, terrain, weather and industrial capacity.  One million people died in the siege of Leningrad alone. Operation Barbarossa was the largest invasion in history. The Germans intended their armed invasion to be brief and effective, and instead it lasted almost four years. Due to the geography of the Soviet Union, the Eastern Front became longer the farther the Wehrmacht advanced; it was also the widest war front in history. The Front was lethal from Poland to Moscow, and then from Moscow to Berlin; the same ground was fought over multiple times.  The Germans had most of the advantages at first, took enormous numbers of prisoners, and let most of the Soviet POWs starve. Almost 4 million Axis troops attacked greater numbers of Soviet soldiers, and the Soviet Union sacrificed their own men readily and through poor leadership from the top. Most Red Army soldiers fought until their ammunition ran out or they died or the situation was hopeless. At the peak, some 11 million soldiers were fighting at the same time. Millions of civilians were in the way of the fighting. Surrender and retreat were discouraged by both dictators. The Nazis intentionally killed civilians. Partisan warfare took place after the front moved to the east, and the Germans took reprisals against civilians.  Modern weapon technology killed millions with tanks, rockets, artillery, machine guns, bombs, strafing, rifles, grenades and mortars; starvation and disease took additional millions.  The competing ideologies made battle fierce and atrocities too common. The industrial economies of the Axis and the Allies constantly supplied weapons to the combatants.
